candidate.name: Hillary Clinton
candidate.bio: The Democratic front-runner, with a bullet, is so far keeping the media at bay, as she plans her first big rally.

candidate.name: Martin O'Malley
candidate.bio: The former Maryland governor made clear when he announced his candidacy last week he will run to Hillary Clinton's left, despite endorsing her in 2008.

candidate.name: Bernie Sanders
candidate.bio: One person who does not mind when you call him socialist, he is expected to shape the Democratic primary despite having little real chance of winning.

candidate.name: Jim Webb
candidate.bio: It is unclear what the former Virginia senator and veteran, a blue dog, will offer to a party that appears to be trending left.

candidate.name: Lincoln Chafee
candidate.bio: The former Rhode Island senator is a Republican turned Democrat who has all but said his candidacy would be more about sending a message than trying to win.

candidate.name: Ben Carson
candidate.bio: The medical doctor is popular in polling, but speaks with no filter and is seen as the longest of shots.

candidate.name: Ted Cruz
candidate.bio: The tea party's last best hope, the Texas senator is a dark-horse prospect for the nomination.

candidate.name: Carly Fiorina
candidate.bio: The only woman among a long list of Republican candidates, she had a controversial turn as CEO of computer-maker HP.

candidate.name: Lindsey Graham
candidate.bio: The hawkish South Carolina senator is a close ally of John McCain, the party's nominee from 2008.

candidate.name: Mike Huckabee
candidate.bio: The former Arkansas governor, TV personality and second-place primary finisher in 2008 is making a bid for social conservatives.

candidate.name: George Pataki
candidate.bio: The former New York governor, a relative unknown nationally, will try to carve out a place in a crowd of moderates in the field.

candidate.name: Rand Paul
candidate.bio: The former New York governor, a relative unknown nationally, will try to carve out a place in a crowd of moderates in the field.The first-term Kentucky senator has drawn fire from his fellow Republicans for his dove-ish stands on war and opposition to domestic surveillance.

candidate.name: Marco Rubio
candidate.bio: One of the establishment favorites, the Florida senator has positioned himself as the next generation of leadership.

candidate.name: Rick Santorum
candidate.bio: He placed second in his scrappy 2012 campaign, but some wonder if the Pennsylvania senator's time has past.

candidate.name: Jeb Bush
candidate.bio: A favorite of the establishment, and the undisputed fund-raising champ nevertheless has a last name that is dragging on his prospects.

candidate.name: Chris Christie
candidate.bio: The so-called Bridgegate scandal has so-far proven just a bump in the road for the straight-talking Jersey governor, but his image as a moderate could prove far more hurtful to his chances.

candidate.name: John Kasich
candidate.bio: The Ohio governor does not have a high profile outside of political circles, but could be a contender if he's not dismissed as too moderate by GOP voters.

candidate.name: Bobby Jindal
candidate.bio: The Louisiana governor believes he cannot go too far right as he tries to get on the national radar and stand out from the pack.

candidate.name: Rick Perry
candidate.bio: A critical gaffe in a debate in 2012 sunk the Texas governor's chances, and he has indicated since then he planned to take another whack at it.

candidate.name: Scott Walker
candidate.bio: The closest thing to a front-runner on the GOP side, Walker of Wisconsin has shown a conservative governor can win big and make changes in blue state.

candidate.name: Donald Trump
candidate.bio: Every election, the TV star and real estate developer flirts with running, and changes his mind, but some say this year might be different. Few are holding their breath.
